fields.content:
{% load pattern_conventions %}

Button-band and Neckline Trim:

Beginning at hem of Right Front and using needles two sizes larger than main needle size, pick up and knit around entire button-band and neckline edge as follows:

Stitches should be picked up and knit at the rate of 1 stitch for every bound-off stitch, 3 out of every 4 stitches along the diagonal, and 2 out of every 3 stitches along vertical sections. Place markers while picking up stitches as follows:

Using larger needles, pick up approximately {{ button_band.stitches }} stitches along right front button band edge, place marker; pick up approximately {{ button_band.neckline_pickup_stitches }} along neck edge, place marker; pick up approximately {{ button_band.stitches }} along left front edge. Approximately {{ button_band.total_veeneck_cardigan_stitches }} stitches; this exact number is not crucial, but should be an even number of stitches.

{% if button_band.num_buttonholes != 0 %}

Work even in {{ button_band.edging_stitch_patterntext}} for {{ button_band.half_height | length_fmt }} (approximately {{button_band.half_height_in_rows_ws}} rows), ending with a WS row.

{% if button_band.evenly_spaced_buttonholes %}

Buttonhole row (RS): Work {{ button_band.stitches_before_first_buttonhole }} stitches, *k2tog, yo, k {{ button_band.inter_buttonhole_stitches }} sts, rep from * {{ button_band.num_interior_buttonholes }} times, [k2tog, yo] once more, work to first marker, slip first marker, then work to end. {{ button_band.num_buttonholes }} buttonholes spaced evenly across right front.

Note: buttonhole instructions should be modified if you did not pick up the specified number of stitches along the right front button band edge.

{% else %}

On last row, place marker at bottom of each desired button hole.

Buttonhole row (RS): *Work to buttonhole marker, *k2tog, yo. Rep from * for each marker, work to end of buttonhole.

{% endif %} {% endif %}

Work as established in {{ button_band.edging_stitch_patterntext}} until trim measures {{ button_band.height | length_fmt}} (approximately {{ button_band.height_in_rows}} rows). BO all stitches.
fields.name: Rosette button band veeneck template

fields.content:
{% load pattern_conventions %}

Right Front Button-band:

Using needles two sizes larger than main needle size, an dbeginning at hem of Right Front, pick up and knit button-band as follows: Pick up and knit stitches at the rate of 2 for every 3 rows along button band edge from hem to neck, approximately {{ button_band.stitches }} stitches. (This number is not crucial, but should be an even number. Buttonhole instructions should be modified if you do not achieve this exact number.)

{% if button_band.num_buttonholes != 0 %}

Work even in {{ button_band.edging_stitch_patterntext}} for {{ button_band.half_height | length_fmt }} (approximately {{ button_band.half_height_in_rows }} rows), ending with a WS row.

{% if button_band.evenly_spaced_buttonholes %}

Buttonhole row (RS): Work {{ button_band.stitches_before_first_buttonhole }} stitches, *k2tog, yo, work {{ button_band.inter_buttonhole_stitches }} sts, rep from * {{ button_band.num_interior_buttonholes }} times, [k2tog, yo] once more, work to end. {{ button_band.num_buttonholes }} buttonholes spaced evenly across front. (Note: If you prefer a different buttonhole than an eyelet buttonhole, please feel free to substitute it.)

{% else %}

On last row, place marker at bottom of each desired button hole.

Buttonhole row (RS): *Work to marker, *k2tog, yo. Rep from * for each marker, work to end.

{% endif %} {% endif %}

Work even in {{ button_band.edging_stitch_patterntext}} until button band measures a total of {{ button_band.height | length_fmt }} ({{ button_band.height_in_rows }} rows). BO all stitches.

Left Front Button-band:

Using needles one size larger than main needle size, and beginning at neck of Left Front, pick up and knit button-band as follows: Pick up and knit stitches at the rate of 2 for every 3 rows along button band edge from neck to hem, approximately {{ button_band.stitches }} stitches. (This number is not crucial, but should respect stitch counts for your stitch pattern. Buttonhole instructions should be modified if you do not achieve this exact number.)

Work even in {{ button_band.edging_stitch_patterntext}} for {{ button_band.height | length_fmt }} (approximately {{ button_band.height_in_rows }} rows). BO all stitches.
fields.name: Rosette button band template
Rosette neckline template

fields.content:
{% load pattern_conventions %} {% with design=piece.get_design %}

Trim Armholes:

Using needles two sizes larger and beginning at underarm seam, pick up and knit {{ piece.total_armhole_stitches }} sts around armhole with a circular needle.

Join for working in the round, being careful not to twist. Work even in {{ design.armhole_edging_stitch_patterntext }} for {{ design.armhole_edging_height | length_fmt }}, then BO all sts.

Repeat for other armhole.

{% endwith %}
fields.name: Rosette armhole template

fields.content:
{% load pattern_conventions %}

Using needles two sizes larger than main needle size, CO {{ piece.cast_ons }} stitches using long tail or other cast-on method of your choice. Work even in {{ piece.hem_stitch_patterntext }} for {{ piece.wrist_hem_height | length_fmt }} ({{ piece.wrist_hem_height_in_rows }} rows), ending with a WS row. Switch to main needle size.

{{ stitch_transition_text }}
fields.name: Rosette sleeve hem template

fields.content:
{% load pattern_conventions %}

Using needles two sizes larger than main needle size, CO {{ piece.cast_ons }} stitches using long tail cast-on or other cast-on method of your choice. Work even in {{ piece.hem_stitch_patterntext }} for {{ piece.waist_hem_height | length_fmt }} ({{ piece.waist_hem_height_in_rows }} rows from beginning), ending with a WS row. Switch to main needle size.

{{ stitch_transition_text }}
fields.name: Rosette waist hem template
Other stitch sleeve hem template
Other stitch waist hem template
Open Mesh Lace sleeve hem template
Open Mesh Lace waist hem template

fields.content:
{% load pattern_conventions %} {% with design=piece.get_design %} {% if piece.vee_neck %}

Beginning at hem of Right Front, pick up and knit around entire button-band and neckline edge as follows:

Stitches should be picked up and knit at the rate of 1 stitch for every stitch and row around entire neckline. Place {{ design.number_of_buttons }} markers for buttonholes as desired on Right Front edge.

{% else %}

Right Front Button-band:

Beginning at hem of Right Front, pick up and knit along Right Front cardigan edge as follows:

Stitches should be picked up and knit at the rate of 1 stitch for every row along button band edge. Place {{ design.number_of_buttons }} markers for buttonholes as desired.

{% endif %}

Using double-pointed needles, CO 3 sts. You will now work an applied i-cord around the cardigan edge. Knit 2 on dpns, slip one stitch knitwise, knit first stitch from circular needle onto dpn, psso. Slide stitches to the right-hand side of the dpn.

Using the other dpn, knit 2, sl1 knitwise, knit second stitch from circular needle onto dpn, psso. Slide stitches to the right-hand side of the dpn.

Continue in this manner until all cardigan edge stitches have been worked, detaching and working i-cord for 2 rows at each button-hole marker. You have a clean, finished edge. Cut yarn and sew in i-cord ends.

{% if not piece.vee_neck %}

Repeat for Left Cardigan front, omitting buttonholes.

{% endif %} {% endwith %}
fields.name: ICord buttonband template

fields.content:
{% load pattern_conventions %} {% with design=piece.get_design %}

Trim Armholes:

Beginning at underarm seam, pick up and knit 1 stitch in every stitch and every row around armhole.

Using double-pointed needles, CO 3 sts. You will now work an applied i-cord around the armhole edge. Knit 2 on dpns, slip one stitch knitwise, knit first stitch from circular needle onto dpn, psso. Slide stitches to the right-hand side of the dpn.

Using the other dpn, knit 2, sl1 knitwise, knit second stitch from circular needle onto dpn, psso. Slide stitches to the right-hand side of the dpn.

Continue in this manner until all armhole stitches have been worked. Bind off 3 remaining i-cord stitches. Cut yarn and weave in ends.

Repeat for other armhole.

{% endwith %}
fields.name: Icord armhole template

fields.content:
{% load pattern_conventions %}

Button-band and Neckline Trim:

Beginning at hem of Right Front, pick up and knit around entire button-band and neckline edge as follows:

Stitches should be picked up and knit at the rate of 1 stitch for every bound-off stitch, 3 out of every 4 stitches along the diagonal, and 2 out of every 3 stitches along vertical sections. Place markers while picking up stitches as follows:

Pick up approximately {{ button_band.stitches }} stitches along right front button band edge, place marker; pick up approximately {{ button_band.neckline_pickup_stitches }} along neck edge, place marker; pick up approximately {{ button_band.stitches }} along left front edge. Approximately {{ button_band.total_veeneck_cardigan_stitches }} stitches; this exact number is not crucial.

{% if button_band.num_buttonholes != 0 %}

Work even in Stockinette Stitch for {{ button_band.half_height | length_fmt }} (approximately {{ button_band.half_height_in_rows_ws }} rows), ending with a WS row.

{% if button_band.evenly_spaced_buttonholes %}

Buttonhole row (RS): Work {{ button_band.stitches_before_first_buttonhole }} stitches, *k2tog, yo, k {{ button_band.inter_buttonhole_stitches }} sts, rep from * {{ button_band.num_interior_buttonholes }} times, [k2tog, yo] once more, work to first marker, slip first marker, then work to end. {{ button_band.num_buttonholes }} buttonholes spaced evenly across right front.

Note: Buttonhole instructions should be modified if you did not pick up the specified number of stitches along the right front button band edge. If you prefer a different buttonhole than an eyelet buttonhole, please feel free to substitute it.

{% else %}

On last row, place marker at bottom of each desired button hole.

Buttonhole row (RS): *Work to buttonhole marker, *k2tog, yo; rep from * for each marker, work to end of buttonhole.

{% endif %}

Continue in Stockinette Stitch until button band measures {{ button_band.height | length_fmt }}, ending with a RS row. Knit one WS row to create turning ridge.

Switch to smaller needles and work in Stockinette Stitch until button band measures {{ button_band.half_height | length_fmt }}, repeat Buttonhole row, then work even in Stockinette Stitch on smaller needles until inside portion of button band measures {{ button_band.height | length_fmt }}. BO all stitches.

{% else %}

Work as established in Stockinette Stitch until trim measures {{ button_band.height | length_fmt}}, ending with a RS row. Knit one WS row to create turning ridge. Switch to smaller needles and work even in Stockinette Stitch until inside portion of button band also measures {{ button_band.height | length_fmt}} (approximately {{ button_band.height_in_rows }} rows). BO all stitches.

{% endif %}
fields.name: Folded Hem veeneck buttonband template

fields.content:
{% load pattern_conventions %}

Right Front Button-band:

Beginning at hem of Right Front, pick up and knit button-band as follows: Pick up and knit stitches at the rate of 2 for every 3 rows along button band edge from hem to neck, approximately {{ button_band.stitches }} stitches. (This number is not crucial, but buttonhole instructions should be modified if you do not achieve this exact number.)

{% if button_band.num_buttonholes != 0 %}

Work even in Stockinette Stitch for {{ button_band.half_height | length_fmt }} (approximately {{ button_band.half_height_in_rows_ws }} rows) ending with a WS row.

{% if button_band.evenly_spaced_buttonholes %}

Buttonhole row (RS): Work {{ button_band.stitches_before_first_buttonhole }} stitches, *k2tog, yo, work {{ button_band.inter_buttonhole_stitches }} sts, rep from * {{ button_band.num_interior_buttonholes }} times, [k2tog, yo] once more, work to end. {{ button_band.num_buttonholes }} buttonholes spaced evenly across front. (Note: If you prefer a different buttonhole than an eyelet buttonhole, please feel free to substitute it.)

{% else %}

On last row, place marker at bottom of each desired button hole.

Buttonhole row (RS): *Work to marker, *k2tog, yo. Rep from * for each marker, work to end. (Note: If you prefer a different buttonhole than an eyelet buttonhole, please feel free to substitute it.)

{% endif %}

Continue in Stockinette Stitch until button band measures {{ button_band.height | length_fmt }}, ending with a RS row. Knit one WS row to create turning ridge.

Switch to smaller needles and work in Stockinette Stitch until button band measures {{ button_band.half_height | length_fmt }}, repeat Buttonhole row, then work even in Stockinette Stitch on smaller needles until inside portion of button band measures {{ button_band.height | length_fmt }} (approximately {{ button_band.height_in_rows }} rows). BO all stitches.

{% else %}

Work even in Stockinette Stitch until button band measures a total of {{ button_band.height | length_fmt }}, ending with a RS row. Knit one WS row to create a turning ridge. Switch to smaller needles and work even in Stockinette Stitch until inside portion of button band measures {{ button_band.height | length_fmt }} (approximately {{ button_band.height_in_rows }} rows). BO all stitches.

{% endif %}

Left Front Button-band:

Beginning at neck of Left Front, pick up and knit button-band as follows: Pick up and knit stitches at the rate of 2 for every 3 rows along button band edge from neck to hem, approximately {{ button_band.stitches }} stitches. (This number is not crucial, but should match Right Front Button-band.)

Work even in Stockinette Stitch for {{ button_band.height | length_fmt }}, ending with a RS row. Knit one WS row to create a turning ridge. Switch to smaller needles and work even in Stockinette Stitch until inside portion of button band also measures {{ button_band.height | length_fmt }} (approximately {{ button_band.height_in_rows }} rows). BO all stitches.
fields.name: Folded Hem button band template
Folded Hem neckline template

fields.content:
{% load pattern_conventions %} {% with design=piece.get_design %}

Trim Armholes:

Beginning at underarm seam, pick up and knit {{ piece.total_armhole_stitches }} sts around armhole with a circular needle.

Join for working in the round, being careful not to twist. Purl one round to create the turning round. Switch to smaller needles. Continue in Stockinette Stitch until internal portion of folded hem measures {{ design.armhole_edging_height | length_fmt }}. BO all sts.

Repeat for other armhole.

{% endwith %}
fields.name: Folded Hem armhole template
Folded hem sleeve hem

fields.content:
{% load pattern_conventions %}

Using needles one size smaller than main needle size, CO {{ piece.cast_ons }} stitches. Work even in Stockinette stitch until piece measures {{ piece.waist_hem_height | length_fmt }} ({{ piece.waist_hem_height_in_rows }} rows) from CO edge, ending with a WS row. Work 1 further RS row even. Switch to main needle size and knit one WS row to create a turning ridge. (Note: All further lengths should be measured to turning ridge, NOT initial CO. Further row counts should be counted beginning with the first row after the turning ridge.)

{{ stitch_transition_text }}
fields.name: Folded Hem waist hem

fields.content:
{% load pattern_conventions %}

CO {{ piece.cast_ons }} stitches. Mark the largest multiple of 4 plus 1 stitches possible in your cast-on count. Work 4 rows even in Garter Stitch.

Switch to Daisy Stitch, keeping any edge stitches in Stockinette, and work until piece measures {{ piece.wrist_hem_height | length_fmt }} (approximately {{ piece.wrist_hem_height_in_rows }} rows), ending with a WS row. (Note: Row count is approximate as your Daisy Stitch row gauge may be different than your main pattern row gauge. If this is the case, subsequent row counts will differ as well.)

{{ stitch_transition_text }}
fields.name: Daisy Stitch sleeve hem

fields.content:
{% load pattern_conventions %}

CO {{ piece.cast_ons }} stitches. Mark the largest multiple of 4 plus 1 stitches possible in your cast-on count. Work 4 rows even in Garter Stitch.

Switch to Daisy Stitch, keeping any edge stitches in Stockinette, and work until piece measures {{ piece.waist_hem_height | length_fmt }} (approximately {{ piece.waist_hem_height_in_rows }} rows from beginning), ending with a WS row. (Note: Row count is approximate as your Daisy Stitch row gauge may be different than your main pattern row gauge. If this is the case, subsequent row counts will differ as well.)

{{ stitch_transition_text }}
fields.name: Daisy Stitch waist hem
One by One Ribbing sleeve hem template
One by One Ribbing waist hem template
Twisted 1x1 Ribbing
fields.notes:
### Twisted 1 x 1 Ribbing (even number of stitches):

**_Row 1 (RS):_** \*Knit 1 tbl, purl 1; repeat to end.

**_Row 2 (WS):_** \*Knit 1, purl 1 tbl; repeat to end.  

### Twisted 1 x 1 Ribbing (odd number of stitches):

**_Row 1 (RS):_** \*Knit 1 tbl, purl 1;  repeat to last stitch, end k 1 tbl. 

**_Row 2 (WS):_** \*Purl 1 tbl, knit 1;repeat to last stitch, end p 1 tbl.

_Note: When working Twisted 1x1 Ribbing in the round, ensure an even number of stitches, and work Row 1 on all stitches for all rounds._

fields.name: Sugar Cube Stitch
fields.notes:
### Sugar Cube stitch:

The Sugar Cube Pattern Stitch is a simple, Stockinette-based stitch pattern with occasional "cubes" of Reverse Stockinette. It is listed as a multiple of 8 stitches, but working the stitch pattern over a different number of stitches is easy - just continue your pattern as established until the end of the row. (Charted version of stitch pattern is available at the end of the pattern.)

Shaping in Sugar Cube pattern is also simple. Work the shaping as specified in your CustomFit pattern, keeping all remaining stitches in Sugar Cube as established. As you increase stitches back in, insert them back into the Sugar Cube pattern, too. 

Sugar Cube Pattern Stitch (multiple of 8 stitches) 

**_Rows 1 and 5 (RS):_** Knit.

**_Rows 2, 4, 6, 8 (WS):_** K the knit sts and p the purl sts. 

**_Row 3:_** K 1, \*p 2, k 6; rep from * to final 7 sts, p 2, k 5.

**_Row 7:_** K 5, \*p 2, k 6; rep from \* to last 3 sts, end p 2, k 1. 

Rep rows 1 - 8.

fields.name: Seed Stitch
fields.notes:
### Seed Stitch (even number of stitches):

**_Row 1 (RS):_** \*Knit 1, purl 1; repeat to end.

**_Row 2 (WS):_** \*Purl 1, knit 1; repeat to end.  

### Seed Stitch (odd number of stitches):

**_Row 1:_** \*Knit 1, purl 1; repeat to last stitch, end k 1. Repeat Row 1.

_(Note: Generally when working Seed Stitch, after working the first row one should knit the purl stitches and purl the knit stitches.)_

fields.name: Rosette Stitch
fields.notes:
### Rosette stitch (even no. sts):

**_Row 1 and 3 (RS):_** Knit.

**_Rows 2 (WS):_** \*P2tog, leave on needle; K2tog on same 2 sts and slide both off needles; rep from \*.

**_Rows 4 (WS):_** P1, rep from \* of Row 2, end p1.

**Note: Rosette Stitch MUST be worked on needles two sizes larger than your main needle size, to ensure a gauge consistent with Stockinette Stitch.**

fields.name: Reverse Stockinette
fields.notes:
### Reverse Stockinette

_**Note:**_ Please be aware that Reverse Stockinette edgings will roll. The rolling will curve inward toward the WS of your garment when worn, and will cause the piece to be shorter than row gauge would typically indicate.

fields.name: Open Mesh Lace
fields.notes:
### Open Mesh Lace (multiple of 3 stitches):

**_Row 1 (RS):_** \*Purl 1, ssk, yo; rep from \* to end. 

**_Rows 2 and 4 (WS):_** \*Purl 2, knit 1; rep from \* to end.

**_Row 3 (RS):_** \*Purl 1, yo, k2tog; rep from \* to end. 

Repeat rows 1 - 4. 

If your cast-on is: 

+ A multiple of 3 stitches plus 1, work an additional "knit one" at the end of your first row. Keep this stitch in Stockinette Stitch.
+ A multiple of 3 stitches plus 2, work an additional "knit one" at the beginning _and_ end of your first row. Keep these stitches in Stockinette Stitch throughout.

If you use Open Mesh Lace to trim a neckline, you may wish to work decreases to ensure your neck edge doesn't flare. We've included optional charts for such decreases, as inspiration. Please feel free to disregard the optional charts if you so choose. 

Open Mesh Lace works best as a cardigan trim when the cardigan has no buttons. If using Open Mesh Lace on a cardigan with buttons, either place the eyelet buttonholes within a final Garter Stitch edge, or work traditional cast-on, bind-off buttonholes.

fields.name: Garter Stripe Stitch
fields.notes:
### Garter Stripe Pattern:

_Please note! Colors are begun on WS rows to properly form the stripes. When working in the round, introduce new colors on your “purl” rounds._

**_Row 1-3 (RS-WS-RS):_** K in MC. 

**_Rows 4-5:_**  K in CC.

**_Rows 6-11:_** K in MC.

**_Rows 12-15:_** K in CC.

**_Rows 16-21:_** K in MC.

Repeat rows 4-21 for pattern.

### Garter Stripe Pattern (Neck):

**_Row 1-2 (RS-WS):_** P in MC; k in MC.

**_Row 3-4:_** P in CC; k in CC.

**_Row 5-10:_** P in MC; k in MC; repeat twice.

**_Row 11-14:_** P in CC; k in MC; repeat once.

**_Row 15-20:_** P in MC; k in MC; repeat twice.

Repeat rows 3-20 for pattern.

fields.name: Garter Stitch
fields.notes:
### Garter Stitch:

When worked flat, knit all rows. When worked in the round, knit one round, then purl one round. *(Note: Garter Stitch gauge often differs from Stockinette Stitch gauge, so row counts (which are computed based on your main pattern swatch) may be different than specified.)*

fields.name: Folded hem
fields.notes:
### Folded Hems:

Please note that you should work all internal portions of the folded hems on needles one size down from your main needle size - this helps the hem lay flat after seaming. 

I find it easiest to work folded hems flat, block them folded shut, and then seamed. Use a simple and flexible whip stitch for the seaming.

fields.name: Daisy Stitch
fields.notes:
### Daisy Stitch (multiple of 4 stitches plus 1):

**_Rows 1 and 3 (RS):_** Knit.

**_Row 2 (WS):_** Knit 1, \*p3tog leaving stitches on the needle, yo, purl the same 3 sts together again and slip them off the needle, k 1; rep from \* to end.

**_Row 4 (WS):_** Knit 1, purl 1, k 1, \*p3tog leaving stitches on the needle, yo, p the same 3 sts together again and slip them off the needle, k 1; rep from \* to last 2 sts, end p 1, k 1.

Repeat rows 1 - 4.

**Notes:** To work Daisy Stitch in the round, CO a multiple of 4 stitches, eliminating the final k 1 on Rows 2 and 4.

Daisy Stitch works best as a cardigan trim when the cardigan has no buttons. If using Daisy Stitch on a cardigan with buttons, either place the eyelet buttonholes within a final Garter Stitch edge, or work traditional cast-on, bind-off buttonholes.

fields.name: Cabled Check Stitch
fields.notes:
### Cabled Check Stitch (multiple of 4 stitches):

**_Left Twist:_** Sl 1 st to CN and hold to front; k1, k1 from CN

**_Right Twist:_** Sl 1 st to CN and hold to back; k1, k1 from CN

**_Row 1 (RS):_** \*Left Twist, p 2; repeat from \* to end. 

**_Row 2 (WS):_** \*K 2, p 2; repeat from \* to end.

**_Row 3 (RS):_**  \*K 2, p 2; repeat from \* to end. 

**_Row 4 (WS):_** \*P 2, k 2; repeat from \* to end.

**_Row 5 (RS):_** \*P 2, Right Twist; repeat from \* to end. 

**_Row 6 (WS):_** \*P 2, k 2; repeat from \* to end.

**_Row 7 (RS):_** \*P 2, k 2; repeat from \* to end. 

**_Row 8 (WS):_** \*K 2, p 2; repeat from \* to end.

(Charted version of stitch pattern is available at the end of the pattern.)

fields.name: Broken Rib Stitch
fields.notes:
### Broken Rib stitch (multiple of 4 stitches):

**_Row 1 (RS):_** \*K 2, p 2; rep from \* to end. 

**_Rows 2 (WS):_** \*Purl.

fields.name: 2x2 Ribbing
fields.notes:
2 x 2 Ribbing (multiple of 4 stitches):

**_Row 1 (RS):_** \*Knit 2, purl 2; repeat from \* to end.

**_Row 2 (WS):_** \*Knit 2, purl 2; repeat from \* to end.  

**_Note:_** When working seamed pieces, a cast-on number that is a multiple of 4 plus 2 stitches is preferred.

If your cast-on is: 

+ A multiple of 4 stitches plus 1, work an additional "knit one" at the beginning of your first row.
+ A multiple of 4 stitches plus 2, work as specified to last 2 stitches of Row 1, end k 2.
+ A multiple of 4 stitches plus 3, work as specified to last 3 stitches of Row 1, end k 2, p 1.

In all cases, WS rows should be worked as follows: Knit the knit stitches and purl the purl stitches.

fields.name: 1x1 Ribbing
fields.notes:
### 1 x 1 Ribbing (even number of stitches):

**_Row 1:_** \*Knit 1, purl 1; repeat to end. 

Repeat Row 1 for pattern.

### 1x1 Ribbing (odd number of stitches):

**_Row 1 (RS):_** \*Knit 1, purl 1; repeat to last stitch, end k 1. 

**_Row 2 (WS):_** \*Purl 1, knit 1; repeat to last stitch, end p 1.
